Dr. Clarence D. Long, professor of economics at Hopkins, was
appointed to the staff of President Eisenhower's Council of
Economic Advisors, Dr. Lowell J. Reed, president of the
university, announced last week.
Dr. Long was named to the staff by Arthur F. Burns, council
chairman, who has been given the task of planning the future
of-the council and rebuilding the agency.
In notifying Dr. Long of his appointment, Mr. Burns wrote:
"I want to bring together a few of the top economists in the
country to work with the council . .. men who are outstanding
general economists, who have a
strong background in economic
theory and statistics, and who have
at the same time a lively interest
in current affairs and in helping
to build the economic future of our
country. I turn to you in hope that
you may find it possible to join this
small group."

...

To Help Rebuild
The council was created in 1946
under the provisions of the Full
Employment Act. Among its important functions is the annual and
semi-annual issuance of a report on
the nation's economic health. This
year, the Council is being completely reorganized under the
Eisenhower Administration.
To. allow him to accept the appointment, the University has
granted Dr. Long a year's leave of
—Parker
absence. He will take up his duties
in Washington in October.
DR. CLARENCE D. LONG
A graduate of Washington and
Jefferson College, Professor Long
received his doctorate at Princeton
in 1938. From 1941 to 1943 he
was a fellow of both the Institute
for Advanced Study at Princeton
and the Guggenheim Foundation,

The 1954 primary elections and
what to do about them will be one
of the topics discussed at the first
business meeting of the Students
for Democratic Action, which will
be held next Friday at 3:00 in
the Levering Hall Board Room.
The campus liberals will try to
bring leading candidates to the
campus from both parties, according to SDA president Bill McCartin. Another possible project due
for discussion this afternoon will
be ways and means of reducing
racial discrimination both on and
off the campus.

Broadcasting from under the
eaves of Maryland Hall, WJHU
plans an enlarged scope of activities for '53-'54.

station will increase its broadcast
time on week nights from one
hour to an hour and a half starting
on October 5, with hopes of a
two-hour stint later in the year.

Hopkins ROTC has instituted a
new "Branch General" program,
similar to those now in use at a
third of all Army ROTC units in.
the country.
This year, members of the first'
three classes will take General
Military Science, while only Seniors will continue with the previous program of Engineering or
Infantry. Next fall all groups will
be trained under this new plan.
In connection with the new Military Science program, commissions will be offered in armor,
artillery, engineering, finance, infantry, medical service, intelligence, military police, ordnance,
quartermaster, transportation and
signal corps.

A New Dorm Program
Over at Alumni Memorial Hall, Dave Jennings, president
of the Dormitory Students Representative Council, has started
a new policy. Assisted by Marshall Turner and Mickey Cochrane,
from the athletic department, and Jim Phinney, social director,
as advisors, Jennings is setting up pilot plant operation for the
new dormitory, which will be open next year. To aid discipline,
he has re-defined the old "code of the gentleman," the guiding
principle of the DSRC, by setting clear and intelligent rules
where formerly the Council relied on the judgment of the
individuals.
Socially, Jim Phinney plans to start a much more extensive
•
program than ever before. He intends to replace some of the
equipment already in the Commons Room, and is installing a
ping-pong table in a game room downstairs. He is thinking in
terms of inter-entry competition in outdoor sports, bridge, and
chess. He has already set up a Hopkins-Goucher committee which
will work to bring Goucher girls to Hopkins athletic events and
to the dormitory social hours which are scheduled to follow them.
He is planning for several discussion and musical evenings.
He is also working on arrangements for several evening dances.
To help him carry out this program, to provide transportation for the Goucher girls, and refreshments for the dances,
and to buy athletic equipment, this week he is asking each dorm
student to pay five dollars yearly dues. We wish him all the success
with this venture.

Lowell Reed expects to remain
president of the Johns Hopkins
University for only three years—
easily the shortest tenure of any
of the University's seven presidents
—but he wants it positively understood that he is not to be considered an interlude or "stopgap"
president.
"As I told the Trustees," he
says, flashing his cherubic grin and
wink, "I am an operator. When I
get the machinery in my hands, I
like to drive it." But he will not
announce any particular goals or
ambitions for his term, since he
feels that he has not been on the
job long enough for such pronouncements.
President Reed took office on
September 1, 1953, emerging from
one of the shortest retirements on
record. After a lifetime of developing and teaching the science of
biostatistics and four years as vicepresident..of the Hopkins Hospital

Kirkpatrick Faces The Test
Since he has taken office this summer, Russell C. Kirkpatrick,
Director of Food Service, has started on a Publicity campaign
of releases to the News-Letter and mimeographed circulars to
employees at Hopkins and students at the dormitory. In almost
all of these he has stressed that suggestions and criticism will be
accepted and judged according to their financial practicality
and their appeal to the majority of those who eat at the dorm
and at Levering Cafeteria.
All this is new to Hopkins, and at the dormitory particularly
represents a radical departure from tradition. Now, the time
has come when Mr. Kirkpatrick 's publicity statements will be
put to test. At the dormitory, although nearly everyone is convinced that the quality of the food has greatly improved, there
has been a general complaint about the quantity. Meanwhile, at
Levering the complaint has been that the quality has declined
slightly, and the size of the serving for a given price has been cut.
We are not in a position to judge the validity of these
complaints, nor to evaluate various ways of dealing with them.
Furthermore, we suspect that a great deal of the complaining
is the standard gripe about the chow which goes on at any
institution. But we feel the complaints are serious enough that
Mr. Kirkpatrick, if he is to continue the start he has made, must
answer these complaints either by action or by An explanation
of the financial picture which does not allow him to meet the.

Dr: Reed received both his B.S.
and his M.S. from Maine, and then
Went to the University of Pennsylvania, where he received his
doctorate in Mathematics in 1915.
Ills instructing at Maine ended
during World War I, when he

Came In 1918
Ile came to Johns Hopkins in
1918, when he was appointed associate professor of biostatistics iii
the School of Hygiene and Public
health, despite a complete lack
of biological training. He was
Was promoted to professor and
department head in 1925, dean of
the school in 1937, vice-president
Of the Hopkins University in 1947,
and vice-president of both Hospital and University in 1949.
his particular specialty is demography—the study of population
growths and trends. He has predicted recent census figures with
an amazing degree of accuracy. He
also has traced the statistical progression of certain diseases and
the movement of molecules within the human body.

Dr. Clarence D. Long, professor of economics at Hopkins, was
appointed to the staff of President Eisenhower's Council of
Economic Advisors, Dr. Lowell J. Reed, president of the
university, announced last week.
Dr. Long was named to the staff by Arthur F. Burns, council
chairman, who has been given the task of planning the future
of-the council and rebuilding the agency.
In notifying Dr. Long of his appointment, Mr. Burns wrote:
"I want to bring together a few of the top economists in the
country to work with the council . .. men who are outstanding
general economists, who have a
strong background in economic
theory and statistics, and who have
at the same time a lively interest
in current affairs and in helping
to build the economic future of our
country. I turn to you in hope that
you may find it possible to join this
small group."

...

To Help Rebuild
The council was created in 1946
under the provisions of the Full
Employment Act. Among its important functions is the annual and
semi-annual issuance of a report on
the nation's economic health. This
year, the Council is being completely reorganized under the
Eisenhower Administration.
To. allow him to accept the appointment, the University has
granted Dr. Long a year's leave of
—Parker
absence. He will take up his duties
in Washington in October.
DR. CLARENCE D. LONG
A graduate of Washington and
Jefferson College, Professor Long
received his doctorate at Princeton
in 1938. From 1941 to 1943 he
was a fellow of both the Institute
for Advanced Study at Princeton
and the Guggenheim Foundation,

A New Dorm Program
Over at Alumni Memorial Hall, Dave Jennings, president
of the Dormitory Students Representative Council, has started
a new policy. Assisted by Marshall Turner and Mickey Cochrane,
from the athletic department, and Jim Phinney, social director,
as advisors, Jennings is setting up pilot plant operation for the
new dormitory, which will be open next year. To aid discipline,
he has re-defined the old "code of the gentleman," the guiding
principle of the DSRC, by setting clear and intelligent rules
where formerly the Council relied on the judgment of the
individuals.
Socially, Jim Phinney plans to start a much more extensive
•
program than ever before. He intends to replace some of the
equipment already in the Commons Room, and is installing a
ping-pong table in a game room downstairs. He is thinking in
terms of inter-entry competition in outdoor sports, bridge, and
chess. He has already set up a Hopkins-Goucher committee which
will work to bring Goucher girls to Hopkins athletic events and
to the dormitory social hours which are scheduled to follow them.
He is planning for several discussion and musical evenings.
He is also working on arrangements for several evening dances.
To help him carry out this program, to provide transportation for the Goucher girls, and refreshments for the dances,
and to buy athletic equipment, this week he is asking each dorm
student to pay five dollars yearly dues. We wish him all the success
with this venture.

Lowell Reed expects to remain
president of the Johns Hopkins
University for only three years—
easily the shortest tenure of any
of the University's seven presidents
—but he wants it positively understood that he is not to be considered an interlude or "stopgap"
president.
"As I told the Trustees," he
says, flashing his cherubic grin and
wink, "I am an operator. When I
get the machinery in my hands, I
like to drive it." But he will not
announce any particular goals or
ambitions for his term, since he
feels that he has not been on the
job long enough for such pronouncements.
President Reed took office on
September 1, 1953, emerging from
one of the shortest retirements on
record. After a lifetime of developing and teaching the science of
biostatistics and four years as vicepresident..of the Hopkins Hospital

Kirkpatrick Faces The Test
Since he has taken office this summer, Russell C. Kirkpatrick,
Director of Food Service, has started on a Publicity campaign
of releases to the News-Letter and mimeographed circulars to
employees at Hopkins and students at the dormitory. In almost
all of these he has stressed that suggestions and criticism will be
accepted and judged according to their financial practicality
and their appeal to the majority of those who eat at the dorm
and at Levering Cafeteria.
All this is new to Hopkins, and at the dormitory particularly
represents a radical departure from tradition. Now, the time
has come when Mr. Kirkpatrick 's publicity statements will be
put to test. At the dormitory, although nearly everyone is convinced that the quality of the food has greatly improved, there
has been a general complaint about the quantity. Meanwhile, at
Levering the complaint has been that the quality has declined
slightly, and the size of the serving for a given price has been cut.
We are not in a position to judge the validity of these
complaints, nor to evaluate various ways of dealing with them.
Furthermore, we suspect that a great deal of the complaining
is the standard gripe about the chow which goes on at any
institution. But we feel the complaints are serious enough that
Mr. Kirkpatrick, if he is to continue the start he has made, must
answer these complaints either by action or by An explanation
of the financial picture which does not allow him to meet the.
demands being made.

Reed's specialties are somewhat
different, he expects to continue
the support of a strong biophysics
department. He points out that
the money for Jenkins Hall was
allocated before Dr. Bronk's appointment.

Dr. Reed played varsity tennis as
a Undergraduate at the University
of Maine, and coached the team
'When he was an instructor there.
Dr: Reed received both his B.S.
and his M.S. from Maine, and then
Went to the University of Pennsylvania, where he received his
doctorate in Mathematics in 1915.
Ills instructing at Maine ended
during World War I, when he
headed the Bureau of Tabulations
and Statistics of the Federal government.
Came In 1918
Ile came to Johns Hopkins in
1918, when he was appointed associate professor of biostatistics iii
the School of Hygiene and Public
health, despite a complete lack
of biological training. He was
Was promoted to professor and
department head in 1925, dean of
the school in 1937, vice-president
Of the Hopkins University in 1947,
and vice-president of both Hospital and University in 1949.
his particular specialty is demography—the study of population
growths and trends. He has predicted recent census figures with
an amazing degree of accuracy. He
also has traced the statistical progression of certain diseases and
the movement of molecules within the human body.
